title: Mapledurham House Walking Route

images.caption: Front of Mapledurham House

images.title: Graham Horn / Rear of Mapledurham House, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rear of Mapledurham House

images.title: John Salmon / Mill, Mapledurham, Oxfordshire
images.caption: Mill, Mapledurham. The mill is driven by the head of water created by Mapledurham Lock and Weir, on the River Thames. It was built in the 15th century, and further extended in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. It is a Grade II* listed building and is preserved in an operational state.

images.title: Rose and Trev Clough / The Almshouses, Mapledurham
images.caption: The Almshouses

images.title: Pam Brophy / Farmland at Mapledurham
images.caption: This section of farmland is utilised as a parking area in the event of open air performances which are held at Mapledurham House during the summer.

images.title: Jeff Tomlinson / Gate Posts with War Memorial
images.caption: Gate Posts with War Memorial

description: The Mapledurham estate is a wonderful place for a relaxing afternoon walk. The house is located on the River Thames with the picturesque Old Watermill right beside it. The mill is still operational and dates from the 15th century. The route below is circular, starting at the house and taking you on a tour of the woodland and countryside in the estate. The park is located near Caversham in Oxfordshire. The estate is located on the Thames Path so you could continue your walk along the river. For example if you head east you will soon come to the delightful Caversham Court Gardens. Heading west will take you to the pretty village of Pangbourne where you can visit the delightful water meadows and enjoy a stroll along the River Pang .
